What is Crush Crush?
Crush Crush is one of those 'clicker' games essentially, but this time you have to attempt to pull girls with your ability to press your mouse at the speed of light. You start off as enemies of some sort, then have to work your way up until you become girlfriends by completing repetitive tasks.

So, the games free to play, are there any sort of microtransactions in game?
Like most free to play games, yes this game comes in a form of microtransactions called 'diamonds', which can be used to speed up the process of many activities and buy certain items in-game early.


Ok, we've got past the boring part, what do you actually get to do in this?
In order to get with the girls in the game, you'll need to level up things such as 'jobs' and 'hobbies' which allow you to complete a certain amount of objectives to progress with the girl. By clicking the character on the main screen however, you gain 'hearts' which is essentially the 'clicker' part of the game. You can however gain multiple amounts of hearts at the same time via 'chatting' to the girls (essentially a one button press and it gives you +25 hearts etc.) and going on dates. There is a wait time behind doing these though, but they're never usually longer than a few seconds.

I've truthfully no idea whether I would recommend this game or not and it's for a variety of factors. I'll cut straight to the chase and say why:

This game is not only fairly original, has good aesthetics, and an overall feel-good and calm-ish sort of tone to it, but it sports some pretty good artwork as well and likeable characters with good designs. It's an amazing blend of the dating sim/idle game genre, and one that makes me feel a sense of accomplishment inside. The pacing at first is phenomenal and begs you to keep playing, but the problem comes from staying on the hype train and noticing that maybe this isn't as good as it was a few prestiges ago.

But there are definitely problems, noticed mostly with prestiging and the downward spiral it creates. Much like prestiging in an FPS game, it takes pretty much longer and longer for you to get any progress in the game as you go through it, going from a happy skip through a meadow into wading through mud that goes up to your hips. The immense slowdown not only jarred me a bit, but left me only wanting more, and constantly tempts me to spend money on gems just so I can get a sense of euphoria again, but that's exactly what they want me to do, and so I fight against it. The gem shop is also a problem as it basically allows the devs to make huge hurdles for you to cross; which of course you can jump over easily with only a small payment of just about $20+ dollars worth of gems.

Essentially, the game is too enjoyable at first to hate, but too boring later to love, and so I'm basically left with a feeling of neutrality. For now, because of my overall experience, I'm going to give this a recommend, but if the system gets even worse with updates I'll likely change that to a no.

Edit: The only honest way I can see this fixed is by uncapping everything multiplier-wise, and making the hurdles not nearly as large as they are right now.

Early Access Review

Early Access Watcher Reviews Crush Crush!

Update Version: 0.32

Disclosure: This is a free to play game with heavy micro-transactions (will explain)

I have never been one to believe in the meaning behind the word free. In the grand scheme of things, nothing can be gained without first sacrificing something to achieve it. Free samples at a Costco or Sam's Club require a membership to enter the store, a free appetizer requires signing up for a rewards program, free miles with a credit card force you to get a credit card, and free to play games are held back by the ultimate sacrifice of time. Crush Crush is an example of a free to play game burdened with the sacrifice of time as everything needed to progress is held back behind a timer. There is a bit of offhand humor and some charming artwork on display, but the ultimate question relies on how much of a pay off it offers. Does this time sink give a memorable journey into the building of a lovely relationship or simply trick the user into a guesswork of plausible worth?

Art can be a matter of taste for any given individual. The character designs to the backgrounds used for inductions and dates are all rather well drawn with very little out of place distractions. Each scene has their own comedic approach on dates that fit the personality of their respected female and the animations used for hobbies and jobs are a wonderful touch. The music is limited and can get old quickly, but the sound effects are downright grating (especially during the first few relationship levels with the girls when you need to click them to progress.) It shows effort and is pleasing to the eye, which is good considering how long you will be seeing them.

The madness begins by meeting your first girl and cookie clicking her to the point she forgives you. Each girl has to be wooed through several relationship levels by meeting certain requirements from hearts gained (either by clicking chat, the girl or over time if you have the right hobby leveled) to gifts and dates spent on them. Upon reaching one of the three landmarks, you are rewarded with a picture of the character. Honestly, the reward for sinking so much time into this game is not that great, but it does let you level while not playing.

You also need to level hobbies and jobs (all over time) to meet certain requirements. Money is generated by the jobs and each time you are paid the job progresses until you are promoted. Hobby levels unlock new jobs and also help unlock new girls to woo. Both have a certain amount of time needed to progress, but you can reset the current game to increase the time multiplier and decrease the amount of time needed to progress. Time blocks are also unlocked when you level up a relationship or job to a certain point which allows you to level more jobs and hobbies at the same time. If it really was this simple, I would have given the game a recommendation for being free and plausible to complete; I then found out the system is rigged.

A free to play game can manage the balance between micro-transactions and time vs reward, but in this case the balance is not achievable. The in-game store uses diamonds (which you are limited to without purchasing them with real money) to increase the speed multiplier, increase time slots for jobs and hobbies and to skip time ahead by 4 hour to 7 days. Right now the multiplier increase from resetting the game is locked at 64x and to increase it further requires real money, which is never mentioned in the game. Time blocks are also limited without using real money and that is never mentioned either. I cannot begin to explain how much time is needed to raise a hobby past 30, let alone 40 and 50 without the use of a multiplier increase. This makes it quite improbable to even reach the eleventh girl's max relationship status (outside the fact you need diamonds to do it) in a reasonable amount of time. This creates a feeling many describe as time dilemma" (I grew victim to it on Eve Online with the skill injects to erase waiting time for skills to level) that can make people flee to the in-game store to buy diamonds in order to complete the game. It is bad enough this gap exists
date: but the developer should have disclosed the limitations on their store page.\n\nMicro-transactions will always be a delicate topic in regards to games. I have grown to accept them in free to play games that are not in beta/early access and even MMOs when they offer cosmetic or pet/mount value. This game
hoursPlayed: does not disclose the free to play and pay to win gap it has created using the ultimate payment of time. I actually like the artwork for this game and thought some of the jokes
voteText: albeit dated
helpfulPercent: were chuckle worthy
votesHelpful:
but this is all pushed to the side when the micro-transactions rear their head. I cannot in good faith recommend this product and plead with the developer to disclose the limitations out of respect to the consumer. I will check back on this product later down the road and hope that my time then will not be put up for auction.

Pros

- Artwork and character models
- Some enjoyable humor and clever characters

Cons

- Micro-transactions with undisclosed limitations
- Sound effects can wear thin after awhile
- Very little reward for the effort"

TL;DR:  Game is a fun daily check in for your virtual waifus where you pretty much make girls fall in love with you by meeting their requirements to advance your realationship with them.

Pretty simple game really, you leave your character either working or leveling up his/her traits for your waifus. I enjoy it for how simple it is and easy to pick up. I would recommend this game for anyone who is bored and needs something to try out but cant commit too much time into. The pros and cons are as follows:

Pros:
-Decent Art, it isn't perfect but still does the game some good
-Appealing characters (to me that is, not everyone may agree).
-Reset for longer play
-Traits/Hearts/Money can be generated while offline.
-Save files
-Simple UI

Cons:
-Music can get repetitive...this is easily fixed by muting it and playing your own.
-Paying gems for saves, hell no. At least the progress is still there though when you check back though.
-Item prerequisites are kinda crazy, although i can see why since making money isn't too hard after a few resets and days of being offline.
-Microtransactions being boosters and time skips, honestly it doesn't surprise me these exist but I am patient enough to wait a few days rather than pay for a skip.

In a nutshell, I give this game a 6/10. It isn't amazing but it is still charming enough for myself to want to check in on it and play it for a little.

Early Access Review

Pros and Cons of the game. It's a bit like HuniePop in a way so people who enjoyed that might enjoy this.

Pros:
Decent characters
It's fun to play
The drawings and game mechanics are not too bad.

Cons:
Long cool down times.
Everything is expensive
You have to use real money if you want more crystals
Getting affection can be hard at times.
Be prepared to prestige A LOT


It takes a ridiculous amount of time for cool downs and earning things. I have six hours for a cool down on a hobby currently. Getting affection can be difficult. Unless you have a lot of money on gifts (in the millions money wise) or are patient when it comes to clicking on the characters to gain affection, be prepared to just exit the game and let the affection pile on after eight or ten hours or else you won't make any progress. That is if you have that unlocked. (The only one who doesn't on mine is Quill)

I think the chat/flirt options when you get further along in each character's story should give the player more than just 44 affection. That's too little for characters that need over 100,000 in affection to progress especially when the gifts are so expensive and some of the gifts don't give much affection either.

I would still reccomend it because I had fun for the first hour and still intend on playing it.

*0.32 version review*
I have spent hours on this and am a bit disappointed that multiplier is capped at 64 despite the text saying you can reset for more. This is a move that spoils quite fun game mechanics, making the game ultimately pay to win. I know it's still early access. Would love to see more to the game too. For now, a negative review so that people don't get disappointed expecting a fair and fun play with optional payments to boost the appeal of the game. I might change the review once good design practices kick in.

*0.34 version review*
*Review crushed!*
Just when I wrote my review, an update came out addressing issue that annoyed me the most. Ok, sure. I can recommend the game now. I cannot assess for certain that game is unpassable in late game for those that would want a challenge with a free game, thus not spending a dime on this game. But the game is fun and I did enjoy it, still do. It has a nice pace of an incremental/clicker game and pleasing visuals to boot.
The game has still some issues, as all early access games do. For example, it only calculated play time while it was active. Which would be a minor bug unless it uses that data for achievements. With an achievement of 1 year play time, it doesn't look too good.
Other than that, more content, more fun. Game looks and plays good and can be improved upon if greed doesn't kick in. Keep it up!

Crush Crush. I genuinely can't state anything, this game is immaculate for the area it targets.
Let's start with the easy bits:

The music and sound effects are cheeky and admirable, succulent and sweet. The mere rhythm of it gets my heart singing, and is quite reminiscent to the music of Phoenix Wright Ace Attorney surprisingly, despite being in different genres. A small song is composed, about 1-2 minutes long, and is looped. As a music nerd, it fits the setting; running around chasing the girls. 8/10

Art design is astounding; the characters and icons are all wonderfully designed, and years for me to click it. It might come off as slightly blurred once in a while, but you need to appreciate the dev's hard work of designing the sprites. 8/10

Right, time for the hard bits:

Stroyline. It comes to happen that you, as the main protagonist, 'crush' into eash individual girl as you meet them. By annihilating their plans, of course they thoroughly dislike the idea of your presence in the first place. However, by providing gifts and talking, you are able to increase their friendship levels to the limit. Of course it's not realistic; it's a video game! But quite imaginative one, and I personally found it pretty comedic. 9/10

Gameplay. Your completely average clicker game, but with quite the twist. You may click, or gift depending on the depth of your pockets or your endurance to click. Personally, the 'girl' clicker game has been taught of multiple times ago, but with a different setting (a.k.a Sakura series). But coming from an Early Access game? There's already so much content that's already been unlocked with the gift system, prestige system, hobby system and job system all being well thought out from hobbies increasing in time duration as and when your level gets higher, to actual promotions in-game based on the amoutn of times you've been 'credited' with in-game currency. And offline capabilities? 7 days? Count me in.

In this week alone, I've played 10 hours of this game. And if there's criticism to be made, it's the fact that there's some text grammatically incorrect, hobbies may take way too long to level-up and girls' demands are quite unbalanced. Iro asks for 2 shoes; approximately 118 million in-game currency at Awkward Besties, when Bonnibel asks for a mere cake at 'Crush' level.

To conclude, despite the flaws, Crush Crush is simply quite the masterpiece for an Early Access and FREE! game. A mixture of cookie clicker and Huniepop, it simply hits the spot for me. Absolute marvel of clicker games.
And if you've come this far, you should know one thing
My waifu is Bonnibel. Touch her, and I'll go Yuno Gasai on you XD

EDIT: Putting some animations in the mix, could prove quite innovative

3. Natural progression: I like how the relationships actually progress. It's not like most date sims where you meet the girl, and she's instantly AAALLLLL over you. It adds more depth to the characters.

4. The player: I actually like the odd looking player avatar, as it's blank. It lets the player envision him or her self in the game easier.

5. Unlimited replayability: This game is a clicker, and it gives the option to restart for a considerable speed boost. There is no real end to the game, and you have to restart, like, 20 times at least.

this is by far my favorite game of all time...okay, it ties with Prototype 2, but still, it's pretty damn good.

Good initial start and has a lot going for, a few thoughts and suggestions though, and if they have been mentioned already, my apologies.


1. Game hits a brick wall around Bonnibel, the jump in requirements is huge compared to the cash and skills being earned
2. The speed multipier, while is perfect early on, again grinds to a halt speed this up and you probably solve number 1 as well
3. After a few days playing I'm now annoyed at buy gifts/dates I can see the requirments on screen then have to click through 2 screens each time (after a few resets this becomes tedious). add a quick buy button to main screen after a certain amount of resets or add a perk tree.

Overall I like it and it's very much in the mould of adventure capatilist, and the points above, although negative are there as advice.

Keep up the good work folks
